title: Can forefoot varus wedges enhance anaerobic cycling performance in untrained males with forefoot varus?
abstract: Full text of this article is available at http://www.sportspa.com.ba/images/dec2010/full/rad1.pdf
rawRecordXml:
<record><header><identifier>
oai:www.e-space.mmu.ac.uk:2173/120492</identifier><datestamp>2011-01-27T15:02:08Z</datestamp><setSpec>hdl_2173_808</setSpec><setSpec>hdl_2173_85256</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd" ><dc:title>Can forefoot varus wedges enhance anaerobic cycling performance in untrained males with forefoot varus?</dc:title><dc:creator>Dinsdale, Nicholas J.</dc:creator><dc:creator>Williams, Alun G.</dc:creator><dc:subject>Cycling biomechanics</dc:subject><dc:subject>Foot orthotics</dc:subject><dc:subject>Foot pronation</dc:subject><dc:subject>WAnT</dc:subject><dc:description>There is limited research relating to cycling biomechanics, and more specifically, the use of foot orthotics to enhance cycling
performance. Therefore, this study investigated the effect of forefoot varus wedges (foot orthotics) on cycling performance, as
measured by anaerobic power output in a population of untrained males presenting with forefoot varus. Six untrained males
(forefoot varus mean ± SD; 6.1 ± 1.7°) completed two separate 30 s Wingate Anaerobic tests (WAnT) on a Monark 824E cycle
ergometer, one with and one without varus wedges, in a counterbalanced order. Although paired-sample t-tests revealed no
significant difference P > .05 in mean power, peak power, and anaerobic fatigue between the two conditions, a Pearson’s productmoment
correlation coefficient (r = .957, n = 6, P = .003) demonstrated that varus wedges offer greater performance benefits to
riders with greater forefoot varus. These preliminary data suggest that correcting forefoot varus using wedges may improve shortterm
power output during cycling for individuals possessing high levels of forefoot varus.</dc:description><dc:description>Full text of this article is available at http://www.sportspa.com.ba/images/dec2010/full/rad1.pdf</dc:description><dc:publisher>Univerzitet u Tuzli</dc:publisher><dc:date>2011-01-27T15:02:08Z</dc:date><dc:type>Article</dc:type><dc:identifier>Sport Scientific And Practical Aspects: International Scientific Journal of Kinesiology, 2010, vol. 7, no. 2, pp. 5-10</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>1840-4413</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>1840-4561</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>http://hdl.handle.net/2173/120492</dc:identifier><dc:language>en</dc:language><dc:relation>http://www.sportspa.com.ba/downloaddece2010.html</dc:relation><dc:relation>http://www.sportspa.com.ba/images/dec2010/full/rad1.pdf</dc:relation></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record>
subject: Article
